member.name: IDataObject.DAdvise
member.summary: Called by an object supporting an advise sink to create a connection between a data object and the advise sink. This enables the advise sink to be notified of changes in the data of the object.
member.param: A pointer to a structure that defines the format, target device, aspect, and medium that will be used for future notifications. For example, one sink may want to know only when the bitmap representation of the data in the data object changes. Another sink may be interested in only the metafile format of the same object. Each advise sink is notified when the data of interest changes. This data is passed back to the advise sink when notification occurs.

param.name: advf
param.para: A group of flags for controlling the advisory connection. Possible values are from the enumeration. However, only some of the possible ADVF values are relevant for this method. The following table briefly describes the relevant values.

listheader.description: ADVF Value
Description
ADVF_NODATA

Asks the data object to avoid sending data with the notifications. Typically data is sent. This flag is a way to override the default behavior. When ADVF_NODATA is used, the tymed member of the structure that is passed to will usually contain TYMED_NULL. The caller can then retrieve the data with a subsequent call.
ADVF_ONLYONCE
Causes the advisory connection to be destroyed after the first change notification is sent. An implicit call to is made on behalf of the caller to remove the connection.
ADVF_PRIMEFIRST
Asks for an additional initial notification. The combination of ADVF_ONLYONCE and ADVF_PRIMEFIRST provides, in effect, an asynchronous call.
ADVF_DATAONSTOP

When specified with ADVF_NODATA, this flag causes a last notification with the data included to to be sent before the data object is destroyed.
If used without ADVF_NODATA, DAdvise can be implemented in one of the following ways:
The ADVF_DATAONSTOP can be ignored.
The object can behave as if ADVF_NODATA was specified.A change notification is sent only in the shutdown case. Data changes prior to shutdown do not cause a notification to be sent.

member.param: A pointer to the interface on the advisory sink that will receive the change notification.
A token that identifies this connection. You can use this token later to delete the advisory connection (by passing it to ). If this value is 0, the connection was not established.

returns.para: This method returns S_OK on success. Other possible values include the following.

listheader.description: Return code
Description
This method is not implemented on the data object.
The value for lindex is not valid; currently, only -1 is supported.
The value for pformatetc is not valid.
The data object does not support change notification.

member.name: IDataObject.DUnadvise
member.summary: Destroys a notification connection that had been previously set up.
member.param: A token that specifies the connection to be removed. Use the value returned by when the connection was originally established.

returns.para: This method returns S_OK on success. Other possible values include the following.

listheader.description: Return code
Description
The specified value for dwConnection is not a valid connection.
This implementation does not support notification.

member.name: IDataObject.EnumDAdvise
member.summary: Creates an object that can be used to enumerate the current advisory connections.
member.param: A pointer to an pointer variable that receives the interface pointer to the new enumerator object. If the implementation sets *ppenumAdvise to NULL, there are no connections to advise sinks at this time.

returns.para: This method returns S_OK if the enumerator object is successfully instantiated or there are no connections. Other possible values include the following.

listheader.description: Return code
Description
Insufficient memory is available for the operation.
Advisory notifications are not supported by this object.

member.name: IDataObject.EnumFormatEtc
member.summary: Creates an object to enumerate the formats supported by a data object.

param.name: dwDirection
param.para: The direction of the data. Possible values come from the enumeration.
The value DATADIR_GET enumerates the formats that can be passed in to a call to . The value DATADIR_SET enumerates those formats that can be passed in to a call to .

member.param: A pointer to an pointer variable that receives the interface pointer to the new enumerator object.

returns.para: This method returns S_OK on success. Other possible values include the following.

listheader.description: Return code
Description
The supplied dwDirection is invalid.
Insufficient memory available for this operation.
The direction specified by dwDirection is not supported.
Requests that OLE enumerate the formats from the registry.

member.name: IDataObject.GetCanonicalFormatEtc
member.summary: Provides a potentially different but logically equivalent structure. You use this method to determine whether two different FORMATETC structures would return the same data, removing the need for duplicate rendering.
member.param: A pointer to the structure that defines the format, medium, and target device that the caller would like to use to retrieve data in a subsequent call such as . The tymed member is not significant in this case and should be ignored.

A pointer to a structure that contains the most general information possible for a specific rendering, making it canonically equivalent to pformatetcIn. The caller must allocate this structure and the GetCanonicalFormatEtc method must fill in the data. To retrieve data in a subsequent call like , the caller uses the specified value of pformatetcOut, unless the value specified is NULL. This value is NULL if the method returns DATA_S_SAMEFORMATETC. The tymed member is not significant in this case and should be ignored.

returns.para: This method can return the following values.

listheader.description: Return code
Description
The returned structure is different from the one that was passed.
The structures are the same and NULL is returned in pformatetcOut.
The value for lindex is not valid; currently, only -1 is supported.
The value for pformatetc is not valid.
The object application is not running.
An unexpected error has occurred.
The dwDirection parameter is not valid.
There was insufficient memory available for this operation.

member.name: IDataObject.GetData
member.summary: Called by a data consumer to obtain data from a source data object. The GetData method renders the data described in the specified structure and transfers it through the specified structure. The caller then assumes responsibility for releasing the STGMEDIUM structure.
member.param: A pointer to the structure that defines the format, medium, and target device to use when passing the data. It is possible to specify more than one medium by using the Boolean OR operator, allowing the method to choose the best medium among those specified.

A pointer to the structure that indicates the storage medium containing the returned data through its tymed member, and the responsibility for releasing the medium through the value of its pUnkForRelease member. If pUnkForRelease is NULL, the receiver of the medium is responsible for releasing it; otherwise, pUnkForRelease points to the on the appropriate object so its method can be called. The medium must be allocated and filled in by GetData.

returns.para: This method returns S_OK on success. Other possible values include the following.

listheader.description: Return code
Description
The value for lindex is not valid; currently, only -1 is supported.
The value for pformatetcIn is not valid.
The tymed value is not valid.
The dwAspect value is not valid.
The object application is not running.
An error occurred when allocating the medium.
An unexpected error has occurred.
The dwDirection value is not valid.
There was insufficient memory available for this operation.

member.name: IDataObject.GetDataHere
member.summary: Called by a data consumer to obtain data from a source data object. This method differs from the method in that the caller must allocate and free the specified storage medium.
member.param: A pointer to the structure that defines the format, medium, and target device to use when passing the data. Only one medium can be specified in tymed, and only the following values are valid: TYMED_ISTORAGE, TYMED_ISTREAM, TYMED_HGLOBAL, or TYMED_FILE.

A pointer to the structure that defines the storage medium containing the data being transferred. The medium must be allocated by the caller and filled in by GetDataHere. The caller must also free the medium. The implementation of this method must always supply a value of NULL for the punkForRelease member of the STGMEDIUM structure to which this parameter points.

returns.para: This method returns S_OK on success. Other possible values include the following.

listheader.description: Return code
Description
The value for lindex is not valid; currently, only -1 is supported.
The value for pformatetc is not valid.
The tymed value is not valid.
The dwAspect value is not valid.
The object application is not running.
An error occurred when allocating the medium.
An unexpected error has occurred.
The dwDirection parameter is not valid.
There was insufficient memory available for this operation.

member.name: IDataObject.QueryGetData
member.summary: Determines whether the data object is capable of rendering the data as specified. Objects attempting a paste or drop operation can call this method before calling to get an indication of whether the operation may be successful.
member.param: A pointer to the structure defining the format, medium, and target device to use for the query.

returns.para: This method returns S_OK on success. Other possible values include the following

listheader.description: Return code
Description
Invalid value for lindex; currently, only -1 is supported.
Invalid value for pformatetc.
The tymed value is not valid.
The dwAspect value is not valid.
The object application is not running.
An unexpected error has occurred.
The dwDirection value is not valid.
There is insufficient memory available for this operation.

member.name: IDataObject.SetData
member.summary: Called by an object containing a data source to transfer data to the object that implements this method.
member.param: A pointer to the structure defining the format used by the data object when interpreting the data contained in the storage medium.
A pointer to the structure defining the storage medium in which the data is being passed.

If TRUE, the data object called, which implements SetData, owns the storage medium after the call returns. This means it must free the medium after it has been used by calling the function. If FALSE, the caller retains ownership of the storage medium and the data object called uses the storage medium for the duration of the call only.

returns.para: This method returns S_OK on success. Other possible values include the following.

listheader.description: Return code
Description
Invalid value for lindex; currently, only -1 is supported.
The value for pformatetc is not valid.
The tymed value is not valid.
The dwAspect value is not valid.
The object application is not running.
The operation failed.
An unexpected error has occurred.
The dwDirection value is not valid.
There was insufficient memory available for this operation.

summary.para: Enables data transfer and notification of changes in data. Data transfer methods specify the format of the transferred data along with the medium through which the data is to be transferred. Optionally, the data can be rendered for a specific target device. In addition to methods for retrieving and storing data, the IDataObject interface specifies methods for enumerating available formats and managing connections to advisory sinks for handling change notifications.

The term data object is used to mean any object that supports an implementation of the IDataObject interface. Implementations vary, depending on what the data object is required to do; in some data objects, the implementation of certain methods not supported by the object could simply be the return of E_NOTIMPL. For example, some data objects do not allow callers to send them data. Other data objects do not support advisory connections and change notifications. However, for those data objects that do support change notifications, OLE provides an object called a data advise holder. An interface pointer to this holder is available through a call to the helper function . A data object can have multiple connections, each with its own set of attributes. The OLE data advise holder simplifies the task of managing these connections and sending the appropriate notifications.
